questions.text: A 53-year-old man comes to the emergency department for severe left knee pain for the past 8 hours. He describes it as an unbearable, burning pain that woke him up from his sleep. He has been unable to walk since. He has not had any trauma to the knee. Ten months ago, he had an episode of acute pain and swelling of the right big toe that improved with analgesics. He has hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus, psoriasis, and hyperlipidemia. Current medications include topical betamethasone, metformin, glipizide, losartan, and simvastatin. Two weeks ago, hydrochlorothiazide was added to his medication regimen to improve blood pressure control. He drinks 1–2 beers daily. He is 170 cm (5 ft 7 in) tall and weighs 110 kg (242 lb); BMI is 38 kg/m2. His temperature is 38.4°C (101.1°F). Examination shows multiple scaly plaques over his palms and soles. The left knee is erythematous, swollen, and tender; range of motion is limited by pain. In addition to administering analgesics, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Blood cultures are part of the diagnostic workup in patients with suspected septic arthritis (SA). The sudden onset of a painful, erythematous joint with a limited range of motion accompanied by fever should raise suspicion for SA. However, this patient does not have any identifiable source of infection (e.g., septicemia, abscesses, wounds, trauma) and his previous history of podagra makes this episode more consistent with an acute gout flare. Although SA should still be ruled out in this patient, another diagnostic step is more appropriate.

B) INCORRECT:

Elevated serum uric acid levels may be found in individuals with acute gout flares. However, they usually fluctuate during flares and patients can have low/normal levels, therefore, serum uric acid is not a reliable indicator for the diagnosis of this condition. The best time to measure serum uric acid in patients with suspected flares is ≥ 2 weeks after the flare subsides. Serum uric acid levels are used primarily to monitor chronic gout and the success of uric acid-lowering therapy (e.g., allopurinol).

C) CORRECT:

This patient's presentation (acute, severe knee pain, swelling, and fever) can be caused by gout, pseudogout, or septic arthritis. While acute gouty arthritis is the most likely diagnosis in this patient, arthrocentesis and synovial fluid analysis (SFA) are indicated to establish a definitive diagnosis if other differential diagnoses (e.g., septic arthritis) cannot be completely excluded. Needle-shaped, negatively birefringent urate crystals on polarized light microscopy of synovial fluid are characteristic of gout.

Empirical therapy without SFA can be started in patients with a high clinical suspicion of gout. Arthrocentesis should be performed if there is an inadequate response to empirical therapy.
Image Description:

Sample of synovial fluid under polarizing light microscopy

Monosodium urate crystals are needle-shaped and appear yellow when their optical axis is oriented parallel to the polarizer. If their axis is perpendicular to the polarizer, they appear blue. The underlying physical principle is called negative birefringence.

Detection of negatively birefringent, needle-shaped crystals in synovial fluid confirms the diagnosis of gout.

D) INCORRECT:

Measuring serum anticitrullinated peptide antibodies (ACPA) is used in the diagnostic evaluation of rheumatoid arthritis (RA). ACPA are highly specific for RA. RA can also affect the knee and patients may present with fever. However, individuals with RA usually report morning stiffness (> 30 minutes) and multiple joints are commonly involved (e.g., metacarpophalangeal and proximal interphalangeal joints). Joint deformities are also characteristic of RA.

E) INCORRECT:

Imaging studies (e.g., knee x-ray) are indicated in patients with suspected gout if first-line diagnostics are unsuccessful/cannot be performed and the diagnosis remains uncertain. An x-ray can help rule out a fracture in patients with posttraumatic joint inflammation and may show features consistent with chronic gout (e.g., punched-out lytic bone lesions), but it is unable to confirm the diagnosis or exclude other important differential diagnoses (e.g., septic arthritis).
questions.hint: This patient presents with a history of podagra in addition to multiple risk factors for gout (obesity, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, psoriasis, thiazide use, and alcohol use). His acutely inflamed knee is most likely the result of an acute gout flare.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man comes to the physician for a follow-up examination. Two weeks ago, he was treated for an acute gout attack of the metatarsophalangeal joints of his right big toe. His symptoms improved with naproxen. He has had three other similar episodes of joint pain in his toes and ankles during the last year that improved with over-the-counter analgesics. He does not currently take any medications. He used to drink 3–5 beers daily but has recently cut down. He is a chef at a steakhouse. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 76/min, and blood pressure is 147/83 mm Hg. Examination of his right big toe shows minimal tenderness; there is no warmth or apparent deformity. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. His serum creatinine concentration is 0.9 mg/dL. Long-term treatment with which of the following drugs is most appropriate to prevent future gout attacks?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Colchicine can be used for the treatment of acute gout attacks. Additionally, it can be given as antiinflammatory prophylaxis to all patients before initiating urate-lowering therapy, which can trigger an acute gout flare by dissolving and mobilizing preexisting urate crystal deposits. Colchicine can prevent an acute gout attack as this drug impairs leukocyte phagocytosis of urate crystals, thereby decreasing the chance of precipitation and acute exacerbation. However, it is ineffective in preventing long-term urate crystal accumulation and thus should be discontinued as soon as persistent normouricemia has been achieved with urate-lowering drugs.

B) INCORRECT:

Probenecid is a uricosuric agent. It is used as second-line therapy or in combination with the preferred agent in patients with chronic gout and multiple exacerbations to prevent gout attacks. Probenecid is mainly indicated for patients with underexcretion because it promotes renal elimination of uric acid.

C) INCORRECT:

Aspirin is not used to treat acute or chronic gout. At low-doses it has even been associated with an increased risk of gout attacks due to reduced renal excretion of uric acid. Therefore, aspirin should be avoided in this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

Oral corticosteroids, such as prednisolone, can be used for acute gout attacks in case of contraindications or lack of response to NSAIDs. However, they do not play a role in the treatment of chronic gout or prophylaxis for acute gout attacks.

E) INCORRECT:

Pegloticase is a uricase medication that catalyzes the breakdown of uric acid to allantoin. It is used as third-line therapy in patients with chronic gout and multiple exacerbations when the preferred drug does not sufficiently decrease uric acid levels.

F) CORRECT:

Urate-lowering therapy (ULT) is indicated in patients with chronic gout and frequent gout attacks (≥ 2 per year). Allopurinol is the preferred first-line urate-lowering drug. Despite its therapeutic effect, it may also trigger an acute gout attack; to prevent this, antiinflammatory prophylaxis (colchicine, NSAIDs, or glucocorticoids) should be given to all patients during initiation of treatment. Febuxostat is an alternative xanthine oxidase inhibitor that can be used as urate-lowering medication in patients with repeated gout exacerbations who have renal insufficiency because, in contrast to allopurinol, it is metabolized in the liver.

Other indications for ULT include tophaceous gout and articular damage due to chronic gout seen on imaging. ULT should also be considered in patients with a first episode of acute gout and significant hyperuricemia (> 9 mg/dL), advanced chronic kidney disease, or a history of urolithiasis.
Image Description:

Acute gout attack: Increases in uric acid concentration or decreases in temperature/pH can lead to the accumulation of urate crystals in various tissues, triggering inflammation. First-line treatment options include NSAIDs, glucocorticoids, and colchicine.

Purine metabolism: Uric acid concentration can increase due to underexcretion (e.g., in chronic renal insufficiency) or over-production (e.g., in tumor lysis syndrome or high dietary purine intake). Xanthine oxidase inhibitors (e.g., allopurinol) inhibit the purine degradation pathway from hypoxanthine to uric acid. Uricosuric medications (e.g., probenecid) inhibit uric acid reabsorption in the proximal convoluted tubules, thus increasing renal excretion. Pegloticase (a recombinant uricase) catalyzes the breakdown of uric acid into allantoin, which is more water-soluble and, therefore, more readily excreted renally.
questions.hint: The patient should receive prophylactic treatment with a xanthine oxidase inhibitor.

questions.text: A 43-year-old man comes to the physician because of left flank pain and nausea for 2 hours. The pain comes in waves and radiates to his groin. Over the past year, he has had intermittent pain in the bilateral flanks and recurrent joint pain in the toes, ankles, and fingers. He has not seen a physician in over 10 years. He takes no medications. He drinks 3–5 beers daily. His sister has rheumatoid arthritis. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows marked tenderness bilaterally in the costovertebral areas. A photograph of the patient's left ear is shown. A CT scan of the abdomen shows multiple small kidney stones and a 7-mm left distal ureteral stone. A biopsy of the patient's external ear findings is most likely to show which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Xanthelasmas are skin deposits composed of lipids, cholesterol foam cells, and multinucleated giant cells. However, they usually develop on the face (particularly around the eyelids). Additionally, this patient has no history of hyperlipidemia, and hyperlipidemia does not explain his joint pain or kidney stones.
Image Description:

Well-defined yellow plaques (xanthelasma) are visible on the medial aspect of the upper and lower eyelids bilaterally.

These cutaneous lipid deposits are a common finding in patients with hypercholesterolemia.

B) INCORRECT:

Struvite stones are composed of ammonium magnesium phosphate and are associated with urinary tract infections (UTIs) with urease-producing organisms such as Proteus mirabilis. This patient has no risk factors for struvite stone formation, such as a history of UTI or indwelling catheter use, which increases the risk of ascending infection.

C) CORRECT:

In combination with his ear findings (tophi), this patient's recurrent joint pain (crystal arthropathy) and intermittent flank pain (nephrolithiasis) suggest chronic gout. Gout is an inflammatory disease caused by elevated serum concentrations of uric acid, which precipitates in body tissues in the form of monosodium urate crystals. Tophi are composed of aggregations of monosodium urate crystals engulfed by multinucleated giant cells, which are surrounded by an inflammatory background of lymphocytes. Common areas of tophi deposition include the pinna of the external ear, tendon sheaths, and synovial bursas. Tophi can also develop in bony structures such as the elbow, knee, and extensor surfaces of the forearm.

D) INCORRECT:

Cystine stones account for approximately 1% of kidney stones and develop in patients with cystinuria, manifesting as early as childhood. This condition is not associated with skin findings and does not explain this man's joint pain.

E) INCORRECT:

Calcium pyrophosphate deposition (pseudogout) also causes paroxysmal joint inflammation but mostly affects the knees and other large joints (e.g., hips, wrists, and ankles). This condition is not associated with skin findings or kidney stones.

F) INCORRECT:

Palisading granulomas are seen in rheumatoid nodules in patients with rheumatoid arthritis (RA). These granulomas are composed of a central area of fibrinoid necrosis surrounded by fibrous tissue, T cells, and plasma cells. Rheumatoid nodules are typically found on the extensor side of the forearm or other bony prominences, but not on the external ear. This patient is at increased risk of RA, given his family history of the disease, and the history of recurrent joint pain in the toes, ankles, and fingers bilaterally raises suspicion for this condition. However, the location of the nodules and the presence of multiple kidney stones on CT scan are not consistent with RA.

G) INCORRECT:

Calcium oxalate stones are the most common type of kidney stones. They are mainly found in patients with hypercalcemia, hypercalciuria, and/or hyperoxaluria. While hypercalcemia can cause bone and joint pain, it is unlikely in a patient with no additional evidence of elevated calcium concentrations, such as cardiac arrhythmias, muscle weakness, polyuria, dehydration, anxiety, fatigue, and/or cognitive dysfunction.
questions.hint: The subcutaneous nodules on this man's external ear should raise suspicion for tophi.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man comes to the physician because of severe pain and swelling of the left knee. He has hypercholesterolemia and hypertension for which he takes pravastatin and losartan. He drinks 4–6 cups of coffee daily. He follows a low-fat diet that includes seafood, leafy green vegetables, and legumes. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 26 years and drinks 2–3 beers daily. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination of the left knee shows swelling, warmth, and severe tenderness to palpation. Arthrocentesis is performed. Gram stain is negative. Analysis of the synovial fluid shows monosodium urate crystals. Which of the following health maintenance recommendations is most appropriate to prevent symptom recurrence?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Losartan has been found to aid in the excretion of uric acid and is the preferred antihypertensive regimen in patients with gout and should not be discontinued. Hydrochlorothiazide should be avoided because it can increase serum uric acid levels and trigger an acute gout flare.

B) INCORRECT:

Alcohol in any form increases the risk of developing hyperuricemia and gout attacks by simultaneously increasing the production of uric acid and limiting its excretion. Therefore, complete cessation of alcohol is recommended for patients with acute gouty arthritis.

C) INCORRECT:

Although all patients are advised to quit smoking, neither smoking nor nicotine affect the excretion or production of uric acid. Smoking cessation will not prevent recurrence of this patient's current symptoms.

D) INCORRECT:

Coffee intake has been shown to lower uric acid levels, which helps prevent future gout attacks. A reduction in coffee consumption is not recommended in patients with acute gouty arthritis.

E) CORRECT:

A low-purine diet, which limits shellfish intake and other purine-rich foods (e.g., red meat, canned fish products, animal organs, bacon), can reduce the risk of gout flares. Consumption of purine-rich foods leads to elevated uric acid levels, which can trigger gout flares. In addition to this lifestyle modification, limited alcohol intake and a reduction in high-fructose corn syrup (e.g., sugary foods, juices, and nondiet sodas), as well as weight loss in overweight patients, can also help manage hyperuricemia and prevent a recurrence.

F) INCORRECT:

Colchicine is commonly used in the acute phase of a gout attack to alleviate symptoms (e.g., joint pain, swelling). However, colchicine primarily inhibits microtubule polymerization and therefore neutrophil chemotaxis and degranulation. It has no role in uric acid production or excretion and is not useful for preventing future attacks.
questions.hint: Monosodium urate crystals found in synovial fluid are consistent with acute gouty arthritis.

questions.text: A 57-year-old man is brought to the emergency department for worsening pain and swelling of his left ankle for the past 2 hours. The pain is severe and awakened him from sleep. He has poorly-controlled hypertension and hyperlipidemia. Current medications include hydrochlorothiazide and pravastatin. His temperature is 37.8°C (100.1°F), pulse is 105/min, and blood pressure is 148/96 mm Hg. Examination shows exquisite tenderness, erythema, and edema of the left ankle; active and passive range of motion is limited by pain. Arthrocentesis of the ankle joint yields cloudy fluid with a leukocyte count of 19,500/mm3 (80% segmented neutrophils). Gram stain is negative. A photomicrograph of the joint fluid aspirate under polarized light is shown. Which of the following is the most appropriate acute pharmacotherapy?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Probenecid is not indicated for the acute management of gout exacerbations, but for maintenance therapy in chronic gout. It inhibits reabsorption of uric acid in the renal tubule, which in turn increases excretion. This agent can be used either as monotherapy or in combination with allopurinol.

B) INCORRECT:

Urate-lowering agents, such as allopurinol, are generally not indicated for the management of acute gout flares but for the management of chronic gout. Administering xanthine-oxidase inhibitors or uricosuric agents during an acute gout flare may worsen symptoms by mobilizing urate crystals. If a patient is already on long-term urate-lowering therapy, it should be continued during the treatment of an acute gout flare.

C) INCORRECT:

Although colchicine might be used in the management of an acute gout flare, urate-lowering agents, such as allopurinol, are generally not indicated for the management of acute gout flares but for the management of chronic gout. Administering xanthine-oxidase inhibitors or uricosuric agents during an acute gout flare may worsen symptoms by mobilizing urate crystals.

D) INCORRECT:

Aspirin is contraindicated in patients with acute gout exacerbations, since it is known to decrease renal uric acid excretion, leading to uric acid retention. In patients already taking low-dose aspirin for specific indications (e.g., coronary artery disease, cerebrovascular disease), it should not be stopped regardless of the severity of gout.

E) INCORRECT:

While monotherapy with oral corticosteroids can be used for the treatment of acute gout exacerbations, it is not commonly given in combination with NSAIDs due to the synergistic adverse effects. In patients treated with both NSAIDs and glucocorticoids, a proton-pump inhibitor should be added to avoid gastrointestinal ulcers.

Oral corticosteroids are preferable in patients with contraindications to NSAIDs such as peptic ulcer disease and chronic kidney disease, or for those that do not respond to other first-line medications.

F) INCORRECT:

While triamcinolone (corticosteroid) can be used as an intra-articular injection for the acute management of acute gouty arthritis involving only 1–2 joints, it should not be used as combination therapy with probenecid. Probenecid is indicated for the management of chronic gout after the acute attack has resolved and in patients with decreased urinary excretion of uric acid.

G) CORRECT:

Anti-inflammatory therapy is indicated for the management of patients with acute gout flares. First-line agents include NSAIDs, colchicine, and glucocorticoids. The choice of treatment is typically based on the patient's age, comorbidities, and drug availability; because this patient has poorly-controlled hypertension, NSAIDs should be avoided. Colchicine is contraindicated in patients with advanced liver disease and severe renal dysfunction, neither of which this patient has a history of. Nonpharmacological measures are also indicated and include rest and ice of the affected joint(s). Urate-lowering agents are generally not indicated for the management of acute gout flares. Administering xanthine-oxidase inhibitors or uricosuric agents during an acute gout flare may worsen symptoms by mobilizing urate crystals.

Modifiable risk factors for hyperuricemia and gout include obesity, hypercholesterolemia, hypertension, a purine-rich diet, and medications (e.g., thiazide diuretics).
Image Description:

Acute gout attack: Increases in uric acid concentration or decreases in temperature/pH can lead to the accumulation of urate crystals in various tissues, triggering inflammation. First-line treatment options include NSAIDs, glucocorticoids, and colchicine.

Purine metabolism: Uric acid concentration can increase due to underexcretion (e.g., in chronic renal insufficiency) or over-production (e.g., in tumor lysis syndrome or high dietary purine intake). Xanthine oxidase inhibitors (e.g., allopurinol) inhibit the purine degradation pathway from hypoxanthine to uric acid. Uricosuric medications (e.g., probenecid) inhibit uric acid reabsorption in the proximal convoluted tubules, thus increasing renal excretion. Pegloticase (a recombinant uricase) catalyzes the breakdown of uric acid into allantoin, which is more water-soluble and, therefore, more readily excreted renally.

H) INCORRECT:

While ketorolac can be used as monotherapy for the acute management of gout exacerbations, it should not be used in combination with aspirin. Aspirin is contraindicated in acute attacks, since it is known to decrease renal uric acid excretion, leading to uric acid retention.
questions.hint: The patient's sudden-onset severe ankle pain and swelling are typical of acute gouty arthritis. The presence of yellow, negatively birefringent crystals on polarized light microscopy of the synovial fluid confirms the diagnosis.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old man with chronic myelogenous leukemia comes to the physician because of severe pain and swelling in both knees for the past day. He finished a cycle of chemotherapy 1 week ago. His temperature is 37.4°C (99.4°F). Physical examination shows swelling and erythema of both knees and the base of his left big toe. Laboratory studies show:


Leukocyte count
13,000/mm3



Serum



Creatinine
2.2 mg/dL


Calcium
8.2 mg/dL


Phosphorus
7.2 mg/dL


Arthrocentesis of the involved joints is most likely to show which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Granulocytes with cytoplasmic inclusion bodies, also known as ragocytes, would be consistent with autoimmune-related arthropathies, including rheumatoid arthritis and SLE. They are not seen in tumor lysis syndrome.

B) CORRECT:

Tumor lysis syndrome occurs when there is widespread lysis of cancer cells (e.g., from chemotherapy), resulting in the release of large amounts of intracellular components such as nucleic acid, which is further broken down to monosodium urate (uric acid). The subsequent hyperuricemia can lead to the precipitation of monosodium urate crystals in the renal tubules and joints, causing acute kidney injury and triggering gout, as seen in this patient. Arthrocentesis of the involved joints would reveal needle-shaped, negatively birefringent crystals.
Image Description:

Tumor lysis syndrome results from the rapid destruction of tumor cells and subsequent massive release of intracellular components. It occurs most commonly in patients with hematologic malignancies (e.g., ALL, AML, or NHL) at the beginning of cytotoxic treatment, but may also occur spontaneously. The accumulation of uric acid crystals can cause acute kidney injury, and the electrolyte imbalances can have life-threatening consequences such as cardiac arrhythmias and seizures.

C) INCORRECT:

Deposition of calcium pyrophosphate crystals within the joint space is the pathomechanism of calcium pyrophosphate deposition disease. Arthritis in calcium pyrophosphate deposition disease commonly affects only one joint (usually the knee), and arthroscopy typically reveals rhomboid-shaped, positively birefringent crystals. The disease is usually idiopathic, but can be caused by hemochromatosis, hyperparathyroidism, or trauma to the joint. Calcium pyrophosphate crystal deposition is not a sequela of tumor lysis syndrome.
Image Description:

Sample of synovial fluid under polarizing light microscopy

Calcium pyrophosphate (CPP) crystals with typical rhomboid shapes. They appear blue when their optical axis is oriented parallel to the polarizer and yellow when their axis is perpendicular to the polarizer (positive birefringence). The overall birefringence of CPP crystals is weak compared to monosodium urate crystals.

D) INCORRECT:

Calcium phosphate crystals are non-birefringent, globular crystals associated with degenerative joint diseases, such as osteoarthritis. Patients with this condition have chronic joint disease of the weight-bearing joints and morning stiffness lasting less than 30 minutes. While tumor lysis syndrome can lead to deposition of calcium phosphate crystals in the kidneys (predisposing to acute kidney injury), deposition of these crystals in the joints is not a sequela of tumor lysis syndrome.

E) INCORRECT:

Gram-negative diplococci in the synovial fluid culture would be concerning for gonococcal arthritis, a type of oligoarthritis commonly seen in sexually active adults. It presents either as monoarthritis (e.g., of the knee), or as polyarthralgia with dermatitis and tenosynovitis. Tumor lysis syndrome does not predispose to gonococcal arthritis.

F) INCORRECT:

Gram-positive cocci in clusters in the joint space would be consistent with septic arthritis due to Staphylococcus aureus. Patients typically present with acute monoarticular joint pain, swelling, and fever. Risk factors include prosthetic joints, skin infection, or IV drug abuse. Tumor lysis syndrome does not predispose to septic arthritis.
questions.hint: This patient presents with elevated creatinine, hyperphosphatemia, and hypocalcemia one week after chemotherapy. This is consistent with tumor lysis syndrome.

questions.text: An 11-year-old boy with Burkitt lymphoma is brought to the emergency department because of nausea, vomiting, flank pain, and dark urine for 1 day. Two days ago, he began induction chemotherapy with cyclophosphamide, vincristine, prednisolone, and doxorubicin. Urinalysis shows 3+ blood and the findings in the photograph. The most appropriate pharmacotherapy to prevent a recurrence of this patient's symptoms has which of the following mechanisms of action?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Free radical neutralization is the mechanism of action of amifostine. Free radical scavengers such as amifostine are used to prevent nephrotoxicity in patients receiving platinum-based alkylating agents (e.g., cisplatin) but are not used to treat or prevent urate nephropathy.

B) INCORRECT:

Inhibition of DNA gyrase is the mechanism of action of fluoroquinolones (e.g., ciprofloxacin), which are used to treat urinary tract infections such as pyelonephritis. Although pyelonephritis can manifest with flank pain, nausea, and hematuria, the presence of urate crystals indicates a different condition.

C) CORRECT:

The use of recombinant uricase and xanthine oxidase inhibitors can prevent urate nephropathy caused by tumor lysis syndrome. Recombinant uricase (e.g., rasburicase, pegloticase) oxidizes urate to allantoin, which is highly water-soluble and excreted in the urine without forming stones. Xanthine oxidase inhibitors (e.g., allopurinol, febuxostat) decrease the serum concentration and urinary excretion of urate by blocking the formation of urate from xanthine and hypoxanthine.
Image Description:

Tumor lysis syndrome results from the rapid destruction of tumor cells and subsequent massive release of intracellular components. It occurs most commonly in patients with hematologic malignancies (e.g., ALL, AML, or NHL) at the beginning of cytotoxic treatment, but may also occur spontaneously. The accumulation of uric acid crystals can cause acute kidney injury, and the electrolyte imbalances can have life-threatening consequences such as cardiac arrhythmias and seizures.

D) INCORRECT:

Inhibition of urate reabsorption in the proximal convoluted tubule is the mechanism of action of probenecid, which is used to prevent chronic gout. However, since probenecid is a uricosuric drug, it would increase rather than decrease the risk of urate nephropathy.

E) INCORRECT:

The consumption of betaine or cranberry juice acidifies the urine, helping to prevent the formation of calcium phosphate and struvite stones, which precipitate in an alkaline environment. Calcium phosphate crystals are wedge- or rosette-shaped and struvite crystals are hexagonal. Uric acid stones precipitate in an acidic environment and urine acidification would increase rather than decrease the risk of urate nephropathy.
questions.hint: Hematuria and rhomboid crystals in the urine are consistent with urate nephropathy, which can occur after chemotherapy as a consequence of hyperuricemia in tumor lysis syndrome (TLS).

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 1-day history of severe pain and swelling in her left great toe. She drinks 6 beers daily. She does not smoke or use illicit drugs. She is allergic to trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole. Examination shows erythema, warmth, and tenderness of the left first metatarsophalangeal joint. The most appropriate next step in treatment is the administration of a drug that has which of the following mechanisms of action?

choices.text: Inhibition of tumor necrosis factor alpha
Increased renal excretion of uric acid

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Methotrexate, which reversibly inhibits dihydrofolate reductase, is a disease-modifying antirheumatic drug used to treat rheumatoid arthritis (RA). Although RA can manifest with joint pain in the metatarsophalangeal joint, patients typically present with symmetrical arthritis. This patient most likely has an acute gout flare, for which methotrexate is not appropriate.

B) CORRECT:

NSAIDs, such as naproxen, are first-line agents in the management of acute gout flares because of their analgesic and antiinflammatory effects. These agents decrease prostaglandin synthesis by reversibly inhibiting the enzymes COX-1 and COX-2. Glucocorticoids and colchicine are also first-line agents for acute gout. The selection of treatment is determined by individual factors, such as comorbidities, potential side effects, and patient preference.

Urate-lowering therapy (e.g., xanthine oxidase inhibitors, uricosurics) is indicated to prevent attacks in patients with chronic gout but should generally be avoided within the first 2 weeks of an acute flare because it can worsen symptoms by mobilizing urate crystals.
Image Description:

Acute gout attack: Increases in uric acid concentration or decreases in temperature/pH can lead to the accumulation of urate crystals in various tissues, triggering inflammation. First-line treatment options include NSAIDs, glucocorticoids, and colchicine.

Purine metabolism: Uric acid concentration can increase due to underexcretion (e.g., in chronic renal insufficiency) or over-production (e.g., in tumor lysis syndrome or high dietary purine intake). Xanthine oxidase inhibitors (e.g., allopurinol) inhibit the purine degradation pathway from hypoxanthine to uric acid. Uricosuric medications (e.g., probenecid) inhibit uric acid reabsorption in the proximal convoluted tubules, thus increasing renal excretion. Pegloticase (a recombinant uricase) catalyzes the breakdown of uric acid into allantoin, which is more water-soluble and, therefore, more readily excreted renally.

C) INCORRECT:

TNF-α inhibitors (e.g., infliximab) are biological disease-modifying antirheumatic drugs used to treat rheumatoid arthritis (RA). Although RA can manifest with joint pain in the metatarsophalangeal joint, patients typically present with symmetrical arthritis.This patient most likely has an acute gout flare, for which TNF-α inhibitors are not appropriate.

D) INCORRECT:

Selective cyclooxygenase-2 inhibitors (COX-2 inhibitors) (e.g., celecoxib) are potent antiinflammatory drugs that can be used to treat an acute flare of gout. Selective COX-2 inhibitors are sulfa drugs, and this patient's allergy to trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole suggests that she is allergic to this class of medicines. Therefore, COX-2 inhibitors are not appropriate.

E) INCORRECT:

Uricosuric drugs like probenecid reduce serum urate by increasing renal elimination of uric acid. They are indicated in the management of chronic hyperuricemia and are not useful in the setting of an acute gout flare.

F) INCORRECT:

Allopurinol and febuxostat are both drugs that act by inhibiting xanthine oxidase. They reduce uric acid levels over time and are, therefore, used in the management of chronic gout. However, they may precipitate flares of acute gout by increasing urate crystal mobilization and should be avoided during the initial stage of acute inflammation.
questions.hint: In a patient with a history of heavy alcohol use, arthritis of the metatarsophalangeal joint suggests acute gout.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 1-day history of sudden severe pain in his right great toe. Four months ago, he had an episode of severe joint pain involving his left knee that lasted several days and resolved with over-the-counter analgesics. He has a history of nephrolithiasis and hypertension treated with hydrochlorothiazide. Examination shows erythema, swelling, warmth, and tenderness of the right metatarsophalangeal joint; range of movement is limited by pain. His serum uric acid is 12 mg/dL. Arthrocentesis yields cloudy fluid with a leukocyte count of 18,500/mm3 (80% segmented neutrophils). Polarized light microscopy of the synovial fluid is shown. Which of the following is the mechanism of action of the most appropriate long-term pharmacotherapy for this patient's condition?

choices.text: Increased conversion of uric acid to allantoin

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Increased conversion of uric acid to allantoin is the mechanism of action of recombinant uricase (e.g., rasburicase, pegloticase), which is a third-line medication for long-term pharmacotherapy of gout. In a patient who is not currently undergoing any medical therapy for chronic gout, a recombinant uricase should not be the first choice.

B) INCORRECT:

Inhibition of phospholipase A is the mechanism of action of glucocorticoids, which is typically used in patients who fail to respond or have contraindications to NSAIDs and colchicine but can be used as a first-line agent for acute gout attacks. Glucocorticoids, however, are not an appropriate long-term pharmacotherapy for gout.

C) CORRECT:

Inhibition of xanthine oxidase is the mechanism of action of allopurinol, which is indicated for the treatment of chronic gout and prophylaxis of acute gout attacks. Indications for long-term pharmacotherapy include recurrent gout flares (≥ 2 gout attacks per year) and evidence of tophi development. Urate-lowering therapy should also be considered in patients with < 2 episodes of acute gout who have hyperuricemia (> 9 mg/dL), advanced chronic kidney disease, or a history of urolithiasis, which qualifies this patient for allopurinol treatment. However, allopurinol should not be initiated within 2 weeks of resolution of the acute gout flare because of the risk of urate crystal mobilization, which can worsen symptoms. When treatment with allopurinol is started, antiinflammatory prophylaxis (colchicine, NSAIDs, or glucocorticoids) should be given as prophylaxis against acute gout attacks.

This patient takes hydrochlorothiazide, which is associated with increased serum uric acid levels. Switching to a different diuretic medication should be considered.
Image Description:

Acute gout attack: Increases in uric acid concentration or decreases in temperature/pH can lead to the accumulation of urate crystals in various tissues, triggering inflammation. First-line treatment options include NSAIDs, glucocorticoids, and colchicine.

Purine metabolism: Uric acid concentration can increase due to underexcretion (e.g., in chronic renal insufficiency) or over-production (e.g., in tumor lysis syndrome or high dietary purine intake). Xanthine oxidase inhibitors (e.g., allopurinol) inhibit the purine degradation pathway from hypoxanthine to uric acid. Uricosuric medications (e.g., probenecid) inhibit uric acid reabsorption in the proximal convoluted tubules, thus increasing renal excretion. Pegloticase (a recombinant uricase) catalyzes the breakdown of uric acid into allantoin, which is more water-soluble and, therefore, more readily excreted renally.

D) INCORRECT:

Increased renal excretion of urate is the mechanism of action of uricosuric medications (benzbromarone, probenecid, lesinurad), which are sometimes used as an alternative treatment or in combination with allopurinol. However, this patient has a history of nephrolithiasis, in which case uricosuric agents are contraindicated because they increase urine uric acid concentration and can precipitate uric acid stones.

E) INCORRECT:

Inhibition of cyclooxygenase is the mechanism of action of NSAIDs and aspirin. NSAIDs are the first-line treatment for acute gout attacks and should be discontinued 2–3 days after the symptoms resolve; they are not indicated for long-term pharmacotherapy of gout. Aspirin is contraindicated in acute gout attacks because it can elevate uric acid levels and thus delay symptom resolution.
questions.hint: This patient presents with a typical history of acute gout and evidence of hyperuricemia (i.e., serum uric acid levels > 7 mg/dL), most likely secondary to thiazide diuretic use and high protein intake (protein is broken down to purines, and eventually into uric acid). The first-line agent for long-term therapy of gout decreases uric acid production.

questions.text: A 63-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 4-hour history of severe pain in the right knee. His temperature is 38.0°C (100.4°F). Examination shows erythema, edema, and warmth of the right knee; range of motion is limited by pain. Arthrocentesis of the knee joint yields cloudy fluid with a leukocyte count of 24,000/mm3 (74% segmented neutrophils). Polarized light microscopy shows needle-shaped, negatively birefringent crystals. Five hours after treatment with a drug is begun, he develops abdominal cramps, diarrhea, and vomiting. The patient was most likely treated with a drug that predominantly acts on which of the following parts of the cell?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Vancomycin interferes with bacterial cell wall synthesis by inhibiting peptidoglycan synthesis. It is used as empiric treatment for septic arthritis caused by gram-positive cocci. Septic arthritis typically presents with fever and monoarthritis, as seen in this patient. However, synovial fluid analysis would show a purulent fluid with a leukocyte count of ≥50,000 cells/mm3 and a positive Gram stain. Moreover, vancomycin is not associated with abdominal cramping, diarrhea, and vomiting shortly after administration. Unlike most prokaryotic cells, eukaryotic cells (including human cells) do not have a cell wall, only a cell membrane.

B) INCORRECT:

NSAIDs exert their antiinflammatory effect by reversibly inhibiting cyclooxygenase, which decreases synthesis of prostaglandins. Naproxen or indomethacin are commonly used for the treatment of acute gout attack. Though prolonged use can cause peptic ulcer disease, NSAIDs are not associated with abdominal cramping, diarrhea, and vomiting shortly after administration. Aspirin is contraindicated in gout as it increases the risk of recurrent flares by decreasing excretion of uric acid.

C) INCORRECT:

Glucocorticoids exert their effect by binding to nuclear receptors (i.e., glucocorticoid receptors) in the cytosol. The glucocorticoid-receptor complex translocates into the nucleus where it downregulates proinflammatory gene transcription. Glucocorticoids are used to treat acute gout attack. However, they are not associated with abdominal cramping, diarrhea, and vomiting shortly after administration.

D) CORRECT:

Colchicine inhibits microtubule polymerization by binding to the cytoskeleton. This leads to disruption of several inflammatory mechanisms, such as phagocytosis of urate crystals, cell chemotaxis, leukocyte activation, and migration. Colchicine is used to treat an acute gout attack, but should be avoided in patients with severe renal or hepatic impairment. Side effects include GI upset as observed in this patient (severe diarrhea, vomiting, abdominal pain), myelosuppression, and hair loss.
Image Description:

Acute gout attack: Increases in uric acid concentration or decreases in temperature/pH can lead to the accumulation of urate crystals in various tissues, triggering inflammation. First-line treatment options include NSAIDs, glucocorticoids, and colchicine.

Purine metabolism: Uric acid concentration can increase due to underexcretion (e.g., in chronic renal insufficiency) or over-production (e.g., in tumor lysis syndrome or high dietary purine intake). Xanthine oxidase inhibitors (e.g., allopurinol) inhibit the purine degradation pathway from hypoxanthine to uric acid. Uricosuric medications (e.g., probenecid) inhibit uric acid reabsorption in the proximal convoluted tubules, thus increasing renal excretion. Pegloticase (a recombinant uricase) catalyzes the breakdown of uric acid into allantoin, which is more water-soluble and, therefore, more readily excreted renally.

E) INCORRECT:

Probenecid inhibits reabsorption of uric acid in the kidney by blocking tubular urate transporters. Although probenecid is a second-line treatment for hyperuricemia associated with chronic gouty arthritis, it is not used for the treatment of acute gout attack. Moreover, it is not associated with abdominal cramping and diarrhea shortly after administration.
questions.hint: This man has acute arthritis of the knee. Arthrocentesis that shows needle-shaped, negatively birefringent crystals confirms the diagnosis of an acute gout attack. Given his gastrointestinal adverse effects, he was most likely treated with colchicine.

questions.text: A 20-month-old boy is brought to the physician for the evaluation of intellectual and behavioral abnormalities and abnormal movements of his extremities. His mother reports that he often hits his head and limbs against furniture. He is unable to walk without support and speaks in unclear 2-word phrases. Examination shows multiple bruises on the forehead and several healing wounds over the fingers. There is increased muscle tone in all extremities. Laboratory studies show an increased serum uric acid concentration. The serum concentration of which of the following substances is most likely to also be increased in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Phenylalanine concentrations are increased in patients with defects in phenylalanine hydroxylase, which causes phenylketonuria (PKU). Although this condition can cause intellectual abnormalities and abnormal movements due to seizures, it does not cause hyperuricemia or self-injurious behavior. Instead, other features, such as growth retardation, dermatitis, or a musty body odor, would be reported. Phenylalanine concentrations are normal in patients with Lesch-Nyhan syndrome.

B) INCORRECT:

Orotic acid concentrations are increased in patients with uridine monophosphate synthase deficiency (orotic aciduria) or ornithine transcarbamylase (OTC) deficiency. Orotic aciduria can cause developmental delay, but it does not cause motor symptoms, self-injurious behavior, or hyperuricemia. OTC deficiency would cause features of hyperammonemia (e.g., vomiting, somnolence, asterixis). Orotic acid concentrations are normal in patients with Lesch-Nyhan syndrome.
Image Description:

The urea cycle is a metabolic pathway specific to the liver that converts cytotoxic ammonia into urea for excretion.

In the mitochondrion, ammonia and bicarbonate react to form carbamoyl phosphate, catalyzed by carbamoyl phosphate synthase and requires two ATP molecules. Carbamoyl phosphate then enters the urea cycle by reacting with ornithine to form citrulline. Citrulline is transported via the ornithine/citrulline antiporter into the cytosol. In an ATP-dependent reaction, argininosuccinate synthase condenses citrulline and aspartate to argininosuccinate. Next, argininosuccinate is cleaved into fumarate and arginine, which in turn is cleaved by arginase into urea and ornithine. Ornithine is transported back into the mitochondrion via the ornithine/citrulline antiporter and thus becomes available for reacting with carbamoyl phosphate in a new cycle. Urea is excreted via the kidneys.

C) INCORRECT:

Adenosine monophosphate and its derivates such as deoxyadenosine triphosphate (dATP) accumulate in patients with adenosine deaminase deficiency, which causes severe combined immunodeficiency. This condition manifests with failure to thrive and severe, recurrent infections in the first year of life. Deoxyadenosine trisphosphate does not accumulate in patients with Lesch-Nyhan syndrome.

D) INCORRECT:

Branched-chain amino acids (isoleucine, leucine, and valine) accumulate in patients with maple syrup urine disease, which manifests during the neonatal period with failure to thrive, ketonuria, and sweet-smelling urine. Branched-chain amino acids do not accumulate in patients with Lesch-Nyhan syndrome.
Image Description:

There are 20 proteinogenic amino acids, which can be classified according to the physical properties of their side chains (polarity, charge). The amino acids with aromatic side chains appear in red here, while the branched-chain amino acids are in blue. Polar, uncharged amino acids include the three amino acids with a hydroxyl group on their side chain, serine, threonine, and tyrosine, which often undergo post-translational modification (phosphorylation), as well as the two derivates of positively charged amino acids aspartate and glutamate, asparagine and glutamine, both of which have a carboxamide group on their side chain.

E) CORRECT:

Phosphoribosyl pyrophosphate (PRPP) is a substrate in the purine salvage pathway that accumulates in patients who have HGPRT deficiency. The inability to regenerate purine nucleotides also leads to an excess of guanine and hypoxanthine bases, which are instead metabolized to uric acid by xanthine oxidase, leading to hyperuricemia. The hyperuricemia seen in patients with Lesch-Nyhan syndrome can be treated by inhibiting xanthine oxidase with allopurinol or febuxostat, but this does not affect the neurological or behavioral features of this condition.
Image Description:

Purine nucleotides are degraded in several steps into uric acid, which is excreted in the urine.

Purine nucleotides (e.g., AMP, IMP, XMP, and GMP) are converted into purine nucleosides. This conversion occurs through hydrolytic cleavage of the phosphate residue and is catalyzed by nucleotidases.

Purine nucleosides are then cleaved into free bases (e.g., hypoxanthine, xanthine, and guanine) by nucleoside phosphorylases.

Xanthine is then oxidized to uric acid by xanthine oxidase, the uric acid is partially reabsorbed, and the rest is excreted in the urine.

F) INCORRECT:

Cytosine monophosphate is a pyrimidine nucleotide. Lesch-Nyhan syndrome is caused by defects in the purine salvage pathway and results in increased de novo purine synthesis; it does not increase the production of pyrimidines.
questions.hint: This boy has Lesch-Nyhan syndrome, an X-linked recessive condition caused by a deficiency of hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyltransferase (HGPRT) that manifests with hyperuricemia, spasticity, dystonia, developmental delay, and self-injurious behavior.

questions.text: A 68-year-old woman with osteoarthritis comes to the physician because of a swollen and painful right knee for the past 2 days. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F). Examination shows erythema and swelling of the right knee with a normal range of motion. An x-ray of the right knee shows punctate radiodensities in both menisci and in the joint capsule. Arthrocentesis of the right knee joint yields 5 mL of cloudy fluid with a leukocyte count of 27,000/mm3. Which of the following is the most likely underlying mechanism of this patient's knee pain?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient has pseudogout, which is caused by calcium pyrophosphate dihydrate crystal deposition within joints leading to episodes of acute inflammatory arthritis. This condition is most common among older adults and often manifests with monoarthritis of the knee that causes swelling, warmth, and tenderness. An x-ray would often show calcium deposits in the cartilage (chondrocalcinosis) as seen here. Arthrocentesis is the gold standard for establishing the diagnosis; examination of synovial fluid typically shows an elevated leukocyte count and rhomboid crystals that are weakly birefringent under polarized light. Certain conditions such as joint trauma, familial chondrocalcinosis, hyperparathyroidism, and hemochromatosis are associated with pseudogout but in most cases, the cause of pseudogout is unknown (primary CPPD disease). Acute treatment for pseudogout includes NSAIDs and intra-articular corticosteroids. Colchicine can be used for prophylaxis.
Image Description:

Sample of synovial fluid under polarizing light microscopy

Calcium pyrophosphate (CPP) crystals with typical rhomboid shapes. They appear blue when their optical axis is oriented parallel to the polarizer and yellow when their axis is perpendicular to the polarizer (positive birefringence). The overall birefringence of CPP crystals is weak compared to monosodium urate crystals.

B) INCORRECT:

Activation of T cells in response to immune complex deposition occurs in patients with rheumatoid arthritis (RA). Though arthrocentesis of affected joints also can also yield cloudy fluid with an elevated leukocyte count (5,000–50,000/mm3), RA clinically manifests with polyarthritis, morning stiffness, and eventual joint deformities (not acute, monoarticular arthritis). Moreover, an x-ray of the affected joint in rheumatoid arthritis would typically show joint space narrowing, juxta-articular osteopenia, bony erosions, and subchondral cysts, not the abnormal punctate radiodensities seen in this case.

C) INCORRECT:

Noncaseating granuloma formation is the pathological hallmark of sarcoidosis. Though an acute presentation of sarcoidosis (Lofgren syndrome) can also cause arthritis, this condition typically manifests with symmetrical and migratory polyarthritis (not monoarthritis) and the abnormal punctate radiodensities that are seen here would not be expected. The typical features of sarcoidosis include fever, uveitis, lupus pernio, erythema nodosum, interstitial lung disease, and bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy.

D) INCORRECT:

Neisseria gonorrhoeae is a gram-negative diplococcus that can cause acute, monoarticular arthritis that manifests with a painful, swollen knee as seen in this patient. However, arthrocentesis of septic arthritis typically results in fever and a leukocyte count > 50,000/mm3. In addition, N. gonorrhoeae arthritis does not cause the abnormal punctate radiodensities seen in this case.

E) INCORRECT:

Monosodium urate crystals deposit within the joints in patients with gout. This condition typically manifests with podagra, but it can also cause tenderness, swelling, and erythema in other joints such as the knee as seen in this patient. However, gout does not cause the abnormal punctate radiodensities seen in this case.
questions.hint: The radiodensities in the menisci and joint capsule on x-ray are caused by chondrocalcinosis.

questions.text: An investigator is studying the efficiency of a new anti-gout drug in comparison to colchicine in an experimental animal model. The test group of animals is injected with the new drug, while the control group receives injections of colchicine. Which of the following cellular functions will most likely be impaired in the control subjects after the injection?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Stereocilia are non-motile membrane protrusions formed by dense, cross-linked bundles of actin filaments. Stereocilia are found in the inner ear, where they enable mechanosensing of sounds and help with balance, as well as in the epididymis and the ductus deferens, where they facilitate absorption of fluid. Since colchicine interferes with the formation of microtubules rather than actin filaments, it would not impair function of the stereocilia.

B) INCORRECT:

Muscle contractions are caused by actin and myosin filaments sliding along each other. Although colchicine does interfere with the cytoskeleton, it inhibits the formation of microtubules rather than actin filaments and would therefore not impair muscle contraction.
Image Description:

Smooth muscles cells are spindle-shaped, have a single nucleus, and contain numerous invaginations in the sarcolemma (caveolae). Because of the irregular arrangement of myofilaments (actin and myosin) in the cell, smooth muscles cells lack sarcomeres (in contrast to striated muscle). Actin filaments are anchored by dense bodies and dense bands, which are linked together by intermediate filaments. Myosin filaments of smooth muscle have an antiparallel arrangement, with the upper and lower rows of myosin heads facing different directions. This allows strong traction to be exerted on the actin filaments (direction of tension indicated by the arrows).

C) INCORRECT:

Nutrient absorption by enterocytes of the small intestine is facilitated by microvilli, as they increase the cell's surface area. Microvilli are finger-like cell membrane protrusions formed by dense, cross-linked bundles of actin filaments. Since colchicine interferes with the formation of microtubules rather than actin filaments, it would not impair nutrient absorption in the body.

D) CORRECT:

Axonal transport is dependent on the polymerization of microtubules; colchicine inhibits this process by binding tubulin in its monomeric form. As a result, microtubule-associated motor proteins (i.e., kinesin and dynein) that transport substances such as synaptic vesicles cannot move along the microtubules. Loss of axonal functions is responsible for the neuromyopathic side effects of colchicine. Microtubule function is also important for cell migration, formation of the spindle apparatus during cell division, and motion of kinocilia and flagella.
Image Description:

In microtubule polymerization, GTP-tubulin dimers (each made up of an α-tubulin and a β-tubulin) accumulate at the plus end. The GTP of β-tubulin spontaneously hydrolyzes shortly afterwards, leading to loss of microtubule stability. Microtubules do not depolymerize if GTP-tubulin dimers are present at the plus end.

The minus end is usually located in the centrosome of the cell, the microtubule organizing center, where it is stabilized by γ-tubulin and capping proteins. In principle, tubulin dimers could also accumulate at the minus end; however, attachment would be very slow (e.g., when a microtubule breaks).

E) INCORRECT:

Transmembrane signal transduction allows an extracellular ligand to exert an effect within the cell. Although the cytoskeleton is thought to play an important role in regulating cell signaling and protein interactions, this function is attributed to a modulation of actin filaments. Colchicine, however, disrupts the function of microtubules and is not known to affect transmembrane signaling.

F) INCORRECT:

Intercellular adhesion allows cells to connect and interact with neighboring cells via cell adhesion molecules (CAMs). These CAMs form complexes on the cell surface (e.g., desmosomes, tight junctions, gap junctions) that are anchored in the cytoskeleton of either cell via actin or intermediate filaments. However, colchicine disrupts the formation of microtubules rather than actin or intermediate filaments, and would therefore not affect intercellular adhesion.
Image Description:

Cell junctions are points of cell-cell or cell-extracellular matrix contact most abundantly found between epithelial cells. There are three major classes of cell junctions:

1. Tight junctions are occluding junctions that close the gaps between epithelial cells and act as a diffusion barrier. They are typically found at the apical aspect of cells.

2. Anchoring junctions are mechanical connections between cells. Based on the anchoring structures and the type of connection, they are divided into:
- Zonula adherens: form cell-cell junctions via actin filaments
- Desmosomes: form cell-cell junctions via intermediate filaments
- Hemidesmosomes: anchor cells to the basement membrane (i.e., cell-extracellular matrix junction) via intermediate filaments and integrins

3. Gap junctions or communicating junctions are intercellular channels that allow the passage of ions and molecules between cells.
questions.hint: Colchicine is an inhibitor of microtubule polymerization.

questions.text: An investigator is studying the activity level of several different enzymes in human subjects from various demographic groups. An elevated level of activity of phosphoribosyl pyrophosphate synthetase is found in one of the study subjects. This patient is most likely to have which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Deficiency of cystathionine synthase results in homocystinuria, which causes an accumulation of homocysteine in tissues and joints. This can lead to lens dislocation, atherosclerosis, bone deformities (elongated bones, kyphosis), and intellectual disability. Homocystinuria is not associated with increased activity of PRPP synthetase.

B) CORRECT:

PRPP synthetase catalyzes the production of PRPP, a substrate for de novo purine and pyrimidine synthesis (i.e., adenosine monophosphate (AMP), guanosine monophosphate (GMP), and uridine monophosphate (UMP)). When purines (AMP, GMP) are degraded, they are metabolized into xanthine and finally uric acid. Thus, increased activity of PRPP synthetase causes an overproduction of purines and subsequent uric acid. Excess uric acid leads to the accumulation of monosodium urate crystals within the joints, causing acute inflammatory monoarthritis.
Image Description:

Biosynthesis of the nucleotide skeleton is an energy-intensive process that must be tightly regulated.
The key enzyme, glutamine-PRPP amidotransferase, is activated by PRPP and inhibited by ADP, ATP, GDP, and GTP.

Not shown here: High levels of ATP promote the formation of GMP, whereas high levels of GTP promote the formation of ATP. Adenylosuccinate synthetase is inhibited by AMP, and IMP dehydrogenase is inhibited by GMP (negative feedback inhibition).

C) INCORRECT:

Maple syrup urine disease is an autosomal recessive disease caused by a deficiency of the branched-chain α-ketoacid dehydrogenase complex, which leads to the accumulation of branched-chain amino acids (i.e., valine, leucine, and isoleucine). It manifests during the neonatal period with poor feeding, failure to thrive, ketonuria, and sweet-smelling urine. Maple syrup urine disease is not associated with increased activity of PRPP synthetase.

D) INCORRECT:

Alkaptonuria is a disorder of tyrosine catabolism caused by deficient activity of homogentisic acid dioxygenase, which catalyzes the degradation of homogentisate to 4-maleylacetoacetate. This leads to the accumulation of pigment-forming homogentisic acid in the serum and the tissues, resulting in ochronosis with subsequent arthritis and degenerative changes in the vertebral column. Alkaptonuria is not associated with increased activity of PRPP synthetase.

E) INCORRECT:

Phenylketonuria is an autosomal recessive disorder caused by phenylalanine hydroxylase deficiency, or rarely, tetrahydrobiopterin deficiency. It leads to the accumulation of phenylalanine in the CNS, resulting in intellectual disability, seizures, growth retardation, and pale skin/hair. Phenylketonuria is not associated with increased activity of PRPP synthetase.
questions.hint: Phosphoribosyl pyrophosphate synthetase (PRPP synthetase) is an enzyme that is involved in the synthesis of nucleotides and converts ribose 5-phosphate into phosphoribosyl pyrophosphate.

questions.text: A laboratory physician investigates the chromosomes of a fetus with a suspected chromosomal anomaly. She processes a cell culture obtained by amniocentesis. Prior to staining and microscopic examination of the fetal chromosomes, a drug that blocks cell division is added to the cell culture. In order to arrest chromosomes in metaphase, the physician most likely added a drug that is also used for the treatment of which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Trichomonas vaginitis is treated with metronidazole, a bactericidal antibiotic that creates free radicals within bacteria and protozoa, thereby inducing DNA-strand breaks. Metronidazole cannot be used to arrest chromosomes in metaphase.

B) CORRECT:

Colchicine is indicated for acute gouty arthritis in patients who cannot tolerate NSAIDs (e.g., patients with chronic kidney disease or gastrointestinal ulcers) or oral glucocorticoids. Colchicine exhibits its anti-inflammatory properties by binding tubulin and thereby inhibiting microtubule polymerization in neutrophils. This prevents urate crystal phagocytosis, leukocyte activation and migration, and cell chemotaxis. In karyotyping, inhibition of microtubule polymerization blocks the formation of the spindle assembly, arresting the chromosomes in metaphase.

Further antimitotic drugs include mebendazole, griseofulvin, vincristine/vinblastine, and paclitaxel.

C) INCORRECT:

Herpes zoster (shingles) is treated with guanosine analogs such as acyclovir, valacyclovir, or famciclovir. These drugs are phosphorylated (by VZV-coded thymidine kinase and other cellular kinases) and incorporated into the replicating viral DNA strand, which inhibits viral DNA polymerase and thereby stops DNA synthesis. Guanosine analogs cannot be used to arrest chromosomes in metaphase.

D) INCORRECT:

Granulomatosis with polyangiitis is treated with cyclophosphamide and corticosteroids. Cyclophosphamide is a nitrogen mustard alkylating prodrug that is bioactivated by hepatic cytochrome P450 enzymes. Once activated, it crosslinks DNA at guanine, which results in the destruction of proliferating B and T lymphocytes. Glucocorticoids bind to glucocorticoid receptors and induce complex changes in gene transcription. Neither of these medications can be used to arrest chromosomes in metaphase.

E) INCORRECT:

Testicular cancer can be treated with cisplatin-based chemotherapy regimens. Cisplatin interferes with DNA repair by inducing intrastrand DNA crosslinks. This leads to the accumulation of DNA damage and subsequent activation of apoptosis within cancer cells. Other chemotherapeutic agents used in testicular cancer include etoposide and bleomycin, which cause the inhibition of topoisomerase II and DNA fragmentation, respectively. None of these agents can be used to arrest chromosomes in metaphase.

F) INCORRECT:

Polycythemia vera (PV) can be treated with hydroxyurea or ruxolitinib. Hydroxyurea inactivates ribonucleotide reductase, which inhibits DNA synthesis and induces cell block in the S phase (and ultimately apoptosis). Ruxolitinib is a JAK2 inhibitor. Neither of these medications can be used to arrest chromosomes in metaphase.
questions.hint: Karyotyping provides a snapshot of all the chromosomes in the cell nuclei and can be used to detect abnormalities in the gross structure and/or number of chromosomes. Karyotypes are prepared with colchicine, which arrests dividing cells in metaphase, when the chromosomes are at their most condensed.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old man with a history of recurrent gouty arthritis comes to the physician for a follow-up examination. Four weeks ago, he was diagnosed with hyperuricemia and treatment with allopurinol was begun. Since then, he has had another acute gout attack, which resolved after treatment with ibuprofen. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F). Physical examination shows painless, chalky nodules on the metatarsophalangeal joint of his right foot. Laboratory studies show:


Serum



Creatinine
1.0 mg/dL


Uric acid
11.6 mg/dL


Cholesterol
278 mg/dL


Urine



Uric acid
245 mg/24 h (N = 240–755)


Based on the urine findings, this patient would most likely benefit from treatment with which of the following drugs to prevent future gout attacks?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Rasburicase catalyzes the breakdown of water-insoluble uric acid to allantoin, which can then be renally excreted. Rasburicase is not used to treat acute or chronic gout, but it is used in the treatment and prevention of hyperuricemia in tumor lysis syndrome.

B) CORRECT:

Probenecid is a uricosuric agent used as second-line therapy or in combination with allopurinol in patients with recurrent gouty arthritis that is not controlled with allopurinol therapy alone. Patients with underexcretion of uric acid, like this man, benefit most from probenecid because this drug promotes renal elimination of uric acid by acting as a competitive inhibitor of reabsorption at the proximal convoluted tubule. In addition, this patient has no contraindications for uricosuric therapy (e.g., impaired renal function, history of nephrolithiasis), making him a good candidate for treatment with this drug.
Image Description:

Acute gout attack: Increases in uric acid concentration or decreases in temperature/pH can lead to the accumulation of urate crystals in various tissues, triggering inflammation. First-line treatment options include NSAIDs, glucocorticoids, and colchicine.

Purine metabolism: Uric acid concentration can increase due to underexcretion (e.g., in chronic renal insufficiency) or over-production (e.g., in tumor lysis syndrome or high dietary purine intake). Xanthine oxidase inhibitors (e.g., allopurinol) inhibit the purine degradation pathway from hypoxanthine to uric acid. Uricosuric medications (e.g., probenecid) inhibit uric acid reabsorption in the proximal convoluted tubules, thus increasing renal excretion. Pegloticase (a recombinant uricase) catalyzes the breakdown of uric acid into allantoin, which is more water-soluble and, therefore, more readily excreted renally.

C) INCORRECT:

NSAIDs, such as indomethacin, are commonly used to treat acute gout attacks, especially in patients who cannot tolerate glucocorticoids. This patient has already recovered from his acute gout attack four weeks ago with the use of ibuprofen. Although NSAIDs are sometimes used to prevent acute gout attacks during treatment initiation with urate-lowering drugs (e.g., allopurinol), they are not indicated for long-term prophylaxis of recurrent gout because they are ineffective in preventing urate crystal accumulation and have potentially serious adverse effects (e.g., gastric ulcers, renal function impairment). This patient's urine findings suggest that a different drug would be more beneficial.

D) INCORRECT:

Oral glucocorticoids, such as prednisolone, are commonly used to treat acute gout attacks, especially in patients who cannot tolerate NSAIDs. This patient, however, recovered from his acute gout attack four weeks ago with the use of ibuprofen. Furthermore, prednisolone is not used to treat chronic gout or prevent recurrent gout attacks.

E) INCORRECT:

Colchicine can be used to treat acute gout attacks in patients who cannot tolerate NSAIDs or glucocorticoids. This patient, however, recovered from his acute gout attack four weeks ago with the use of ibuprofen. Although colchicine can also be used to prevent acute gout attacks during treatment initiation with urate-lowering drugs (e.g., allopurinol), this drug is not indicated for long-term prophylaxis of recurrent gout because it is ineffective in preventing urate crystal accumulation and has serious adverse effects (e.g., neuromyopathy). This patient's urine findings suggest that a different drug would be more beneficial.
questions.hint: This patient underexcretes uric acid (i.e., normal urinary uric acid excretion in the presence of hyperuricemia) and would most likely benefit from a uricosuric agent to help manage his symptoms.

questions.text:
Patient Information
Age: 55 years
Gender: M, self-identified 
Race/Ethnicity: unspecified
Site of Care: office
History
Reason for Visit/Chief Concern: follow-up after diagnosis of myasthenia gravis 
History of Present Illness:

diagnosed with myasthenia gravis 2 months ago
started treatment with pyridostigmine but had to be discontinued due to several episodes of bradycardia
initiated treatment with prednisone and azathioprine 1 month ago
eye muscle weakness has improved significantly

Past Medical History:

hypertension
gout
osteoarthritis

Medications:

amlodipine
allopurinol
prednisone
azathioprine
ibuprofen as needed

Vaccinations:

Which of the following would have prevented this near miss?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Rarely, ibuprofen can cause hemolytic or aplastic anemia. Ibuprofen-induced pancytopenia is extremely rare; a different cause is more likely.

B) INCORRECT:

Systemic glucocorticoids (e.g., prednisone) can cause leukocytosis and increased hemoglobin and red blood cell counts, but not pancytopenia. Withholding prednisone and prescribing azathioprine monotherapy would not have prevented the development of pancytopenia, as azathioprine can cause pancytopenia.

C) INCORRECT:

Supplementation with folic acid is indicated for patients receiving drugs that may cause folate deficiency (e.g., methotrexate). This patient is not receiving any drugs that cause folate deficiency, and folate deficiency would cause anemia, not pancytopenia.

D) CORRECT:

This patient's pancytopenia was likely caused by the interaction between azathioprine and allopurinol. Azathioprine is metabolized to 6-mercaptopurine (6-MP), which causes immunosuppression at low dosages and is cytostatic at high dosages. Allopurinol inhibits xanthine oxidase, which is responsible for the degradation of 6-MP. Concomitant administration of a xanthine oxidase inhibitor causes a toxic accumulation of 6-MP resulting in bone marrow suppression. A thorough assessment of potential drug interactions before initiating azathioprine could have prevented the development of pancytopenia in this patient. Coadministration of azathioprine and allopurinol should be avoided. The dose of azathioprine (or any other purine analog) should be reduced if concomitant administration with allopurinol is unavoidable.

Alternatives to azathioprine with less impact on bone marrow, such as cyclosporine, would have been a safer option for this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

A CT scan of the chest is indicated in all patients with myasthenia gravis to assess for a thymoma or thymic hyperplasia. Thymomas are associated with pure red cell aplasia and immunodeficiency, but not pancytopenia.
questions.hint: This patient has pancytopenia.

questions.text:
An 82-year-old man with a history of hypertension, type 2 diabetes, and gout is evaluated for toe pain at a skilled rehabilitation facility, where he was admitted one week ago after undergoing aortic valve replacement for severe aortic stenosis. Near the end of the hospitalization for his surgery, hydrochlorothiazide and lisinopril were added to his medication regimen.
He currently has a temperature of 37.8°C and a heart rate of 80 beats per minute. He has erythema, warmth, and swelling of his right great toe, with tenderness to palpation, particularly at the metatarsal-phalangeal joint. His pedal pulses are 1+ bilaterally.
Which one of the following conditions is the most likely cause of this patient’s fever, joint pain, and swelling?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Cholesterol emboli typically manifest as a petechial rash after an interventional procedure performed via arterial access (usually the femoral artery).

B) INCORRECT:

Charcot joints develop gradually in patients with neuropathy; they do not cause acute swelling and pain.

C) INCORRECT:

A septic joint could have a similar presentation, but given the patient’s history of gout and the recent initiation of treatment with a thiazide diuretic, acute gout is the most likely diagnosis.

D) INCORRECT:

Ischemia would cause a cold foot or toe. Depending on the location of obstruction to arterial flow, the corresponding foot pulses may be absent or diminished compared with the contralateral side.

E) CORRECT:

Acute gouty arthritis is typically characterized by erythema, warmth, swelling, pain, and tenderness in one or more joints. Although virtually any joint can be involved, the lower extremities are more commonly affected than the upper extremities. Low-grade fever may occur. Acute gouty arthritis can be precipitated by initiation of treatment with a thiazide diuretic, which tends to raise serum uric acid levels.

A septic joint could have a similar presentation, but given the patient’s history of gout and the recent initiation of treatment with a thiazide diuretic, acute gout is the most likely diagnosis.

Key learning point: Thiazide diuretics can trigger a gout flare.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old man with stage 4 chronic kidney disease and a serum creatinine level of 3.0 mg/dL (reference range, 0.8–1.3) reports severe pain and swelling in his left knee that began suddenly 3 days ago. A day later, he developed pain and swelling in his right knee and ankle, as well as both feet. The pain has become so severe that he is now unable to walk, prompting him to go to the emergency department.
On examination in the emergency department, the patient has a temperature of 37.3°C, a heart rate of 85 beats per minute, and a blood pressure of 112/82 mm Hg. Warmth, marked tenderness, erythema, and limited range of motion are noted in both knees, the right ankle, and both first metatarsophalangeal joints. His knees also have moderate effusions.
Arthrocentesis of the right knee reveals inflammatory synovial fluid with a leukocyte count of 42,000 per mm3 ; many intracellular and extracellular negatively birefringent, needle-shaped crystals; and a negative Gram stain.
Which one of the following initial therapies is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Intra-articular methylprednisolone 40 mg into each knee

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Colchicine is thought to have similar efficacy to NSAIDs and glucocorticoids if it is taken within the first 24 hours of a gout flare. However, it should be avoided in patients with significant renal or hepatic impairment.

B) INCORRECT:

Intra-articular glucocorticoids are a good option for monoarticular or oligoarticular gout flares but are not adequate when multiple joints are affected.

C) INCORRECT:

Although NSAIDs are generally effective in most cases of acute gouty arthritis, they contraindicated in patients with significant kidney dysfunction.

D) CORRECT:

The diagnosis of acute gouty arthritis is confirmed by the presence of negatively birefringent, needle-shaped monosodium urate crystals inside and outside leukocytes within synovial fluid. The recommended treatment is antiinflammatory therapy with nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), colchicine, or glucocorticoids (systemic or intra-articular). The choice of which drug to use depends on patient factors, including preferences and especially comorbidities. In this particular case, a systemic glucocorticoid is the best choice because multiple joints are affected and the patient has contraindications to other treatment options.

The initial dose of prednisone used in this setting varies depending on patient characteristics and the number of joints affected. Typical starting doses can range from 30 mg to 40 mg daily. Once flare resolution begins, the drug is typically tapered over 7 to 14 days.

Key learning point: The most appropriate treatment for a patient with advanced chronic kidney disease who develops severe polyarticular acute gouty arthritis is systemic glucocorticoid therapy.

E) INCORRECT:

Uricosuric agents, such as allopurinol, reduce uric acid levels and are indicated for the chronic treatment of gout. However, they do not alleviate acute gout flares and may exacerbate gout if they are initiated in the absence of gout prophylaxis.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old woman who underwent a kidney transplant 5 years ago presents with a chief complaint of pain and swelling in the first metatarsophalangeal joint. She first experienced the pain yesterday upon waking; today, it has worsened to the point where she cannot walk. The patient has no history of trauma and no family history of arthritis or crystalline arthropathy. Her current daily medications are losartan 50 mg, cyclosporine 400 mg, azathioprine 100 mg, prednisone 5 mg, and vitamin D supplementation 250 μg (10,000 IU).
Physical examination reveals erythema, swelling, tenderness, and decreased range of motion of the first metatarsophalangeal joint. Fluid aspirated from that joint contains monosodium urate crystals; Gram stain and cultures are negative. Laboratory testing is notable for a uric acid level of 10.4 mg/dL (reference range, 1.5–6.0) and a creatinine level of 1.5 mg/dL (0.6–1.1).
Which one of this patient’s medications is most likely contributing to her hyperuricemia?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Hyperuricemia is not strongly associated with the use of azathioprine, high-dose vitamin D, or prednisone, and some studies suggest that losartan may lower serum levels of uric acid.

Notably, azathioprine metabolism is impaired by the use of allopurinol, a xanthine oxidase inhibitor, such that the addition of allopurinol can lead to marked azathioprine-related toxicity. Therefore, the two medications should be used together very cautiously. If allopurinol is started in a patient taking azathioprine, an effort should be made to find an alternative immunosuppressive agent before the allopurinol is added. If no alternative is possible, then allopurinol should be introduced very cautiously (50 mg daily or less), and the dose of azathioprine may need to be reduced by 75% or more.

B) INCORRECT:

Hyperuricemia is not strongly associated with the use of azathioprine, high-dose vitamin D, or prednisone, and some studies suggest that losartan may lower serum levels of uric acid.

C) CORRECT:

Gout is frequently seen in patients with a history of organ transplantation. Use of cyclosporine, a medication commonly taken after transplantation, is a known risk factor for hyperuricemia. Cyclosporine also reduces hepatic metabolism of colchicine, which makes managing gout particularly challenging in this situation. Alternatives to cyclosporine can be considered for transplant recipients with gout. For example, tacrolimus is associated with a lower risk of hyperuricemia than cyclosporine.

Key learning point: Among solid organ transplant recipients, hyperuricemia is frequently associated with the use of cyclosporine.

D) INCORRECT:

Hyperuricemia is not strongly associated with the use of azathioprine, high-dose vitamin D, or prednisone, and some studies suggest that losartan may lower serum levels of uric acid.

E) INCORRECT:

Hyperuricemia is not strongly associated with the use of azathioprine, high-dose vitamin D, or prednisone, and some studies suggest that losartan may lower serum levels of uric acid.

questions.text:
